title: Letters to the Editor:  Disney Gets What It Deserves. Will Florida?
text:
Paybacks are hell. Even those of us troubled by government retaliation can be forgiven our schadenfreude at Florida's abolition of the Reedy Creek Improvement District ("Revolt in Disney's Florida Kingdom," Review & Outlook, April 22). The Walt Disney Co. certainly earned that by its hubris.

On the other hand, the Reedy Creek district originally served -- indeed, still serves -- a public purpose in providing essential governmental services for the very large tract of land that encompasses Disney World. Special districts are established to meet special circumstances.

As to Epcot, the Magic Kingdom and the rest of Disney World, the parks themselves and their infrastructure are well maintained and well run. I have said that Reedy Creek may be the world's only socialist economy that actually works. The Reedy Creek Improvement District certainly is responsive to its constituents; we should all be so fortunate. That is hardly likely to be the case if governance falls to Orange County and Osceola County.

Roger Leemis

Southfield, Mich.

---

You quote Gov. Ron DeSantis saying "I don't support special privileges in law, just because a company is powerful." Now please ask if Mr. DeSantis feels that same way about The Villages. My guess is that he doesn't care to look hard into the special privileges enjoyed by the group that runs The Villages as its fiefdom.

J. Brad Peebles

North Palm Beach, Fla.

---

Concerning our governor's quest to terminate Disney's favored tax status: Where is Sen. Elizabeth Warren when you need her to lecture us on corporate welfare? Oddly, she is nowhere to be found.

Paul J. Schilling

Saint Augustine, Fla.
